reviewText: "Race movies," a genre unique to the United States between 1915 and 1947, were quite popular with black Southern audiences and in Northern industrial cities that had large African American communities. After the successful legal desegregation of the film industry in 1948, this type of movie vanished, literally. Today, only a fifth of the original 500 race films still exist.SYNOPSES:"The Black King" - Bud Pollard directed this story of a Baptist minister who starts a "Back to Africa" movement, but is then accused of swindling money from his followers. This movie, made by a white-owned company, was billed as a satire on the life of Marcus Garvey, an early black separatist. (After a fraud conviction, Garvey was deported to Jamaica in 1925-- he is now recognized as a hero of that island nation.)"Junction 88" is an all-black community where Lolly (Cooke) lives. She wants to marry unsuccessful songwriter Buster (Clark), but her father (Smith) has another, much cruder man named Onnie (Junior) in mind for son-in-law, as he can provide for Lolly. Appearing as themselves: Vaudeville comic Pigmeat Markham and ragtime composer Noble Sissle. Musical highlight is a jazzy church concert.ALPHA VIDEO is a provider of vintage programming that's often unavailable elsewhere. Their prices are fair, but so is transfer quality of some of their offerings. None have undergone restoration, yet this product's rareness and an honest price make it a worthwhile purchase.Also recommended:The Harlem Double FeatureGANG WAR/BROKEN STRINGS.Parenthetical numbers preceding titles are 1 to 10 viewer poll ratings found at a film resource website.(5.2) The Black King (1932) - A.B. DeComathiere/Vivianne Baber/Knolly Mitchell/Dan Michaels/Mike Jackson(6.4) Junction 88 (1947) - Bob Howard/Dewey 'Pigmeat' Markham/Noble Sissle/Wyatt Clark/Marie Cooke/Augustus Smith/George Wiltshire/Herbert Junior
summary: Fictionalized story of Marcus Garvey / 40s musical with Noble Sissle
Title: Junction 88 / The Black King

reviewText: Loved season one that I could stream so much that I bought season one. Well worth the money, may even buy!
Title: Junction 88 / The Black King

reviewText: Why are these so expensive? I should not have bought the 7-day rentals, because now I want to watch them over and over, and I can't justify buying the DVDs. Too much money. Perhaps it's not Amazon's fault, but it's somebody's greedy fault! That said, Henning Mankell's Wallander series are awesome, wonderful, tight, with good lighting, direction, editing, sound and acting. Especially Krister Henriksson as Wallander. But I love them all.
Title: Junction 88 / The Black King

reviewText: The mystery of it.  I am still trying to discern the meaning in this title. Certainly not a U.S. Rapp celebrity.  One of the best of the Wallander series.  I would give it a 6 stars if the choice were available. word word word.
summary: I mourn the passing of this series and look forward to having Alzheimer's so I can watch them all again unremembered!
Title: Junction 88 / The Black King

reviewText: The title of this one is not a good translation of the original Swedish title and seems to bear no relation to the story, which is in any case something of a credibility stretch. As always the acting is good and the setting quite intriguing but this is one of the poorer episodes.
Title: Junction 88 / The Black King
